Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Fluorescent Dyes and Pigments by Small Molecule Isolation Lattices, SMILES
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is related to the development of fluorescent materials. Commercial potential is expected to emerge when replacing costly existing technologies (like quantum dots) with inexpensive materials able that can be embodied as highly fluorescent organic solids. Such materials are expected to create new value and have commercial potential in several markets in which either aesthetics, brightness, or color transmission is critical for performance. Our primary markets of interest are colorants in paints and polymers. Fluorescent brighteners represent an important segment of the global dyes and pigments market (a >$30B per year industry). We believe our technology can expand this segment by streamlining the formulation and processing of fluorescent materials, and by broadening the available color palate. Immediate applications would arise in creation of new fluorescent paints and coatings for construction and safety applications, and may also provide new user-friendly color options to the growing market for 3D printing materials. We anticipate additional downstream applications to arise in customized biolabeling technologies and solar power generation. If successful, the broader impacts also include the training of scientists in the process of commercialization.

This I-Corps project provides a universal tool to address the outstanding intellectual challenge of understanding how to reverse loss of fluorescence from solid-state formulations of organic dyes. The intellectual merits will derive from new synthetic preparations of fluorescent dye and pigment technology by a method called small molecule isolation lattices, or SMILES. This project derives from research that has provided a way to insulate the color-carrying dye molecules from one another allowing their fluorescence to be rescued. A wide range of proof-of-principle experiments shows how to prepare the SMILES materials simply by mixing a proprietary compound with existing fluorescent compounds. The results show fluorescence in solids, as films, crystals, dyes, and particles under identical conditions that render conventional fluorescent dyes non-emissive.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merits revolved round identifying possible advantages associated with the underlying discoveries. Upon making the “go” decision, a startup was founded based upon the business model that had been constructed during customer discovery. Each member of the I-Corps team currently has a role with the startup: Entrepreneurial lead Benson is now a full time employee of the business with a dual role as both chief scientist and chief executive officer; principal investigator Flood has a part time role as the chief technology officer for the business; industry mentor Miller has a part time role as a business development consultant. The business began operations in December of 2018, opening a lab and office space in Indianapolis in February of 2019. A license for the patent underlying the fluorescent pigment technology is currently being negotiated with Indiana University, and a collaboration between the startup and PI Flood’s research group has been established. In addition, the business model discovered during I-Corps was used as the basis for a successful Phase I Small Business Innovation Research grant (SBIR) submission with the National Science Foundation.  

The broader impacts of the project were many and varied. These include professional development and training in the commercialization of the people supported by the project, Benson, Flood and Miller. Contacts made during the I-Corps program have resulted in the formation of several significant collaborative relationships that have had a beneficial impact on the early activities of the business. Several of the most important are listed below (the identities of these companies are withheld). A fluorescent materials company is currently in discussions with the business to support scale- up of precursors for the fluorescent pigments. A consumer products company has gifted the startup with custom paints to use as a test material for the fluorescent pigments and has offered to compensate the startup for its co-development and consulting work. A color technology company has expressed interest in providing technical advice and performance testing on color packages developed from the fluorescent pigments, while also facilitating introductions to multinational companies that might serve as early customers. A polymer designer and manufacturer has offered to provide the startup with high-grade polymer resins to test the pigment materials as well as providing access to their research laboratories and color development team to study the behavior of the fluorescent pigments. A chemical company performed thermal stability analyses of some fluorescent pigment materials and has offered future use of their analytical laboratory.
